comments.body: I think pytest / standard lib have other ways to monkeypatch as well -- reviewer should perhaps weigh in on this.
This seems like a fairly pointless test for me - you're going to have a bad time in general if `sys.executable` doesn't exist. It's probably true in embedded python interpreters, but that's about it

Is it sufficiently pointless that I can remove catching the `OSError` in the source code itself? If not, it seems like it is sensible to at least probe a code path that raises such an error. Perhaps there's a less aggressive way to raise the error though.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +127,131 @@    # patch the sys Python exe path temporarily to
    # induce an OSError downstream
    # NOTE: how bad of an idea is this patching?
    try:
        temp = sys.executable

comments.body: Is the column alignment of this fortran important? If so, would probably be good to add a comment to that effect.
